Plantation.plantation: They are now providing several ships to transport the governor, treasurer, and marshal of Virginia, with their companies, together with other private plantations, to the number of 400 persons.

Plantation.fishing: A thousand of our own nation with many good and warlike ships, who of necessity must defend the fishing season for their living's sake, as they always formerly have done in the wars with Spain.

Plantation.settlement: The captain and one of the chief persuaders of others, who afterwards broke from the society of the colony and, like outlaws, retired into the woods to make a settlement and habitation there, were on their party, with whom they purposed to leave our quarter and possess another island by themselves.

Plantation.colony: And for this misgovernment, chiefly our colony is much bound to the mariners, who never yet in any voyage hither have made a prey of our poor people in want

Plantation.plant: It was ordained that for every head they should plant but a thousand plants of tobacco, and for better strength, not to suffer above nine leaves to grow on each plant. This will make about a hundred weight.

Plantation.tobacco: The cola is much like our bigger sort of chestnut, flat on both sides, yet without a hard shell. The taste is very bitter, yet it causes that which is taken immediately after to be very sweet—water tasting like white wine and sugar, and tobacco also having thereby an admirable sweetness.

Plantation.wild: They never see the king, unless it be when he passes through the gardens to some sport, or when he takes a boat, or else when he goes hunting, for he makes them serve instead of hounds to hunt wild beasts.

Plantation.savage: In the morning, the master and others saw two savage who had been on the island near our ship. What they came for we could not tell, for they were going so far back again before they were described that we could not speak with them.

Plantation.habitation: But we neither could, nor yet desired to do it, because we had less cause to trust them, being that they alone had formerly made an assault upon us in the same place, during our winter discovery for habitation.

London.london: Lying a hull as though they had been in a whirlpool, the waters making no less noise to be heard afar off than the waterfall of London Bridge.

London.city: The other voice sounding towards the middle of the city in these words: "Many good things are done in thee, O thou fair city."

London.money: He sent notice to the king, who seemed to be offended with the Moors, giving them leave to lade themselves out of their ships, paying them their money laid out.

London.gold: He had on every finger three rings of gold and had his body anointed with oil of storax and benzoin.

London.bell: They had diverse steeples and bells in them, one so great that they had never seen so great a bell in Europe.

London.babylon: For Calisthenes sent unto Aristotle, how that Babylon was far more famous for all kinds of learning and knowledge twelve hundred years past than it was when Alexander the Great did besiege it, certifying him with records of nineteen hundred years before Alexander's time.

London.venice: All the jewelry of Venice is not worth one of them.

London.hall: The round table hanging in the great hall at Winchester is falsely called Arthur's Round Table; it is not of sufficient antiquity and contains 24 seats.

London.crowded: Moreover, we may see our streets crowded with a heap of young gentlemen who have much ado to maintain themselves, and yet they must have attending pages to trudge with tokens or love-scripts to madame or mistress many-better.

Obedience.obedient: That now he could produce fairer fruits of amity, being obeyed by all his nobility than before when he himself was made obedient to one and to another, and ruled as it were rather by entreating than by power or commandment.

Obedience.correction: Yet as they do under correction of the more learned, that those speculations about the real distinction of faculties in such spiritual substances as are the angels and souls of men, are but mere subtleties of the school, without any true ground in nature itself.

Obedience.instruction: Philosophers may serve for our instruction and pricking forward: as also the examples (which are lively reasons) of the lives of so many notable men, as histories, the mother of antiquity, do as it were represent alive before our eyes.

Obedience.humility: Who did their obeisance with marvelous humility. The king was a man of tall stature and seemed to be much delighted with the sound of our music.

Obedience.adoration: Fountain of all that life which is in the world, is most worthy of all: the adoration, joy, love, and confidence of our hearts, and the best improvement of that life which he hath given us.

Obedience.acknowledge: Yet because it resembles a capitol of so many princes, rather than a parliament house, where the subject however great acknowledges his monarch; we will allow him emperor, as I have said, for good manners' sake; but questionless standing at the devotion of his imperials and cities; it diminishes his glory, and obscures the shining of his three crowns.

Obedience.ignorance: Names were never heard nor known, till blindness' blossoms were full blown, and ignorance had with their fames almost hid both themselves and names; of Noah, Nimrod, and the rest, of those great worthies, then at least, each one with might and main did strive, from gods their lineage to derive; then Jove and Saturn honored were, for gods, some are so wise, they fear huge idols, stocks, and floods, as Nile, Anubis, and the so did the Egyptians and their superstitions did overspread a great part of the world.

Obedience.subjection: So did his internal cogitations conspire against him to be revenged on him for his sin; and now that man is reconciled and acquitted by the final sentence of the great judge, all his unruly and rebellious perturbations are brought into subjection.

Obedience.bondage: Neither is this bond without bondage, whilst neither the man nor the woman have power over their own bodies: nor may make any separation.

Treachery.robbery: When he came into the fields, seeing a flock anywhere, he violently took one sheep and gave it to his family to eat, and marveled that I would not eat of his robbery.

Treachery.factious: For the avoiding of sects and factions in religion, the governor and council shall be careful to suppress by course of authority all factious and seditious preaching, teaching, and disputing, as well in private as in public.

Treachery.ingratitude: For, in the fight with us, in the vice-admiral, he was wounded and maimed in such a manner as a punishment for his ingratitude. Three years after, I saw him begging with crutches, in such a miserable state that he had been better off dead than alive.

Treachery.deceit: Why have you lied unto us, promising by deceit that no Spaniards would enter these countries? And why have you burnt our gods, seeing the Spaniards bring us other gods from other nations?

Treachery.villain: I saw with mine own eyes, in the presence of much people, villain deflowers a most beautiful woman as she was coming forth of the bath.

Treachery.idolatry: So vile and filthy is their idolatry, so obscene and shameless their lives, so ridiculous their incantations, so exorbitant their presenting of virgins to be deflowered by idols, so abominable their exorcisms, and so odious their senseless profanation, with lamentable obstinacy not to be diverted.

Treachery.cruelty: For although he found unlooked-for glorious cities and well-compacted governments, yet was he fain by strong hand to overthrow their idols and punish their obstinacy with cruelty.

Treachery.betraying: But alas for you, good father, I am right sorry for your hard hap; who are to answer before God and the world for the betraying of your country no fewer times than thrice already.

Treachery.villany: And that many monarchs and kings, notwithstanding their assayers, tasters, and other vigilant care to prevent such villainy, have been poisoned and died cruelly, such as Alexander the Great, Drusus, Claudius Caesar, Charles the Fifth of that name, King of France, John, King of England, and diverse others.

Treachery.treachery: This may be due to the nature and condition of the matters he is to handle, the treachery and perfidiousness of those with whom he is to deal, the malice and emulations (either public or private) which are never wanting in courts, or the jealousy of princes, who (as Comineus well notes) do easily suspect and distrust their best servants in matters concerning their state.

Duty.glory: There is a seed by thee now to be sown, in whose fruit earth shall see her glory shown, at all parts perfect.

Duty.policy: Above all things, good policy is to be used, that the treasure and moneys in a state be not gathered into few hands.

Duty.fidelity: For they do not only perform great obedience to the laws: they adore and venerate their princes in God's stead. All spiritual judges (after Mahomet's law) are accounted among them for saints, men of all equity and integrity, fidelity and opinion.

Duty.quality: Without doubt, according to the quality of the earth, those which are to discover are without comparison far more in number than those which are yet discovered.

Duty.charity: By the help of the holy masses, matins, suffrages, almsdeeds, pilgrimages, and other good works of piety and charity had at this time, I am delivered.

Duty.excellency: The decoction of the juice is of such excellence, that if steel-edged tools red hot be drenched and cooled therein oftentimes, it makes them so hard that they will cut stone or iron, be they never so hard, without turning the edge or waxing dull.

Duty.authority: Because this was not terrible enough to the rest, and he was desirous to arm justice with the authority of all the commanders, forthwith he caused a martial court to be called.

Duty.majesty: So did he the same likewise by this discovery abroad, but the accomplishment of both was reserved for his majesty now reigning, and no prince in the world may more easily effectuate such a purpose since his dominions afford abundance of brave men singularly valued for able bodies and active spirits whereof the English have already given good proof of their sufficiency in foreign plantations.

Duty.property: From whence we may learn that it is the property of true charity to neglect the present reward.

Duty.country: You who esteem your country honor more than life or pelf, (which peasants do adore) your noble ancestors, whose memories are borne by fame as far as the rise.

Duty.devotion: In perpetual alms, Edreds Hith, with the appurtenances, with such devotion, that they shall send every year twenty pounds.

Lazy.sloth: This Demetrius in times past had been sent out of the way into Gnidos by his father, fearing the doubtful chances of the war: and he entered upon this action by occasion of the contemptible sloth and cowardice of the said Alexander.

Lazy.dull: The next day having some sour looks of the king, he came aboard with a dull spirit.

Lazy.naughty: The mind is there defiled with corrupt thoughts, the affections with naughty desires, the ears by hearing, and the eyes by seeing, all which are so lewd.

Lazy.debauched: This is true only of the ruder sort, an objection answered. And more debauched; and so pertains not to thee.

Lazy.disorderly: Thirdly, they are disorderly in their proceedings. Fourthly, they neglect all laws of government, not punishing the bad or rewarding the good.

Lazy.filthy: The rotten dregs and filthy matter of every vicious vanity, be purged, evacuated, and emptied out of the soul, by contrition of heart, compunction of spirit, confession of mouth, and actual dereliction.

Lazy.stupid: What man can be so stupid that discerns not his pride? Thus you may see what contrariety there is betwixt their profession and practice.
